creditline: Gift of Ruth and David Waterbury in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts
description: structure of seven figures attached made out of thorns painted black; one small figure twisted and separate; two removable lids/caps fit on top of each of the taller elements
marks: Signature, Date and Sticker on underside of c, incised: [Sengel / \'00]
medium: Ebonized pearwood, rose and locust thorns
text:
Family Portrait is a group of interconnected, black-painted wood and thorn figures, whose heads are tiny, functional boxes. Sengel sees the “prickliness” as characteristic of many family gatherings. He explains his motivation: 
“Leafing through an old family photo album and then seeing a batch of locust thorns that I had stuck into a piece of foam board led me to the idea of this piece. Despite the darker, ominous associations of black thorns, an element of whimsy was irrepressible here. I see this as portrait, caricature, silhouette…it is still one of my favorites.”
title: Family Portrait
